Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Analysis and Solution Methods for Function Robust Optimization Models

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to study a new class of optimization models where general shape constraints specify the function form, and a maximin criterion is used to resolve the function ambiguity. For many data driven decision problems the functions specifying the problem are obtained from the data through model fitting. This model fitting is done based on a presumed form of the function. The decisions are subsequently made by optimizing the fitted functions. In the modeling framework the function set is specified using properties of the function and non-parametric model fitting. Such problems are called function robust optimization problems. Different types of function robust models will be analyzed and algorithms will be developed for solving these models.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to the development of a new class of optimization modeling techniques and algorithms for solving such models. The solutions obtained from such models are expected to be more robust and efficient under data uncertainty when compared to those obtained from the classical known approaches. A general methodological framework that allows ambiguity in the function form will present a significant conceptual advancement to the field of optimization based decision making. Applications of such problems range from topics in management, intelligent control, and engineering design. Experiments will be performed to validate the algorithms, and to compare the properties of the solutions generated from the new modeling technique.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Real-world decision making problems often face huge systematic complexity and environment uncertainty with concomitant information incompleteness, data error, etc. These issues highly challenge in modeling these problems mathematically precisely so that obtained optimal solutions are neither correct nor stable. A typical example is to make a risk-averse decision without fully learning the decision maker’ risk attitude. Another example is that an imprecise estimation of demand function impedes seeking the best pricing strategy.

We have proposed the novel concept of functional robustness, which is a worst-oriented approach to decision making problems under the risk due to imperfections made in assessing the physical model formulations of systems. This concept bridges machine learning and robust optimization. The key idea is that, if it is difficult to precisely estimate the underlying model of a system, a set of models is specified using statistics and machine learning to ensure that the underlying model is contained in the set with high confidence and robust optimization is applied to seek the best and stable solution over the set.   

The new optimization methodology can be widely applied into manufacturing, marketing, energy, health care etc. We have implemented this concept into expected utility maximization problems. Expected utility maximization is a broadly-used risk-averse modeling technique for seeking the best solution in regards to the decision maker’ risk preference. A restriction is ambiguity and inconsistency in characterizing the preference.  Using the concept of functional robustness, we search for optimal solutions over an ambiguity set of preferences. Our studies have proposed four different specifications of the preference sets, analyzed their properties, and developed fast solution methods.  Another implementation is to model collaborative decision on pricing and inventory under the uncertainty of demand function. In this study, we have developed a data-driven approach to specify the set using the least squares regression method.
